prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: GAMA 9 field (west)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Targets within GAMA 9 field with RA<09:00:00.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We have used the redshifts and the Herschel fluxes to predict the total flux in Band 7 for each source. The predicted fluxes range between 50 and 150 mJy. We have calculated the required sensitivity in two ways. First, we assume that there is no structure on a scale larger than 1 arcsec, the scale of the structure detected by Bussmann et al. (2013). To be conservative we assume that the source emission is spread over a circle of diameter 1 arcsec, equivalent to 70 resolution elements (beam of 0.12 arcsec). We calculate the integration times by requiring a 5sigma detection in each beam area. Second, we assume that the emission is distributed in an Einstein ring of diameter 3 arcsec. Using the lens model that we have derived for the Herschel source ID81 (Dye et al. 2014), we find that the emission is spread over 105 beam areas. Requiring a 5sigma detection in each beam, we obtain a similar sensitivity requirement to the one from the first assumption.
In the latter test case, the maximum scale for Band 7 is similar to the scale of the lensing signal that we are looking for. However, for gravitational rings and arcs, most of the power in the fourier domain is on smaller scales. To ascertain whether loss of flux is important, we have used the ALMA Observation Tool to observe our simulated lensed source (diameter of Einstein ring of 3 arcsec), finding that the loss of flux in the ring is <5%.
The source in our sample that will be at the lowest elevation from ALMA is at a declination of 35 degrees, where the beam size in declination is increased by a factor of 1.8. As a conservative assumption, when we investigated the accuracy with which we could recover the source structures and density profiles (Fig. 3a), we have used the beam size for this source.
The spectral resolution (27 km/s) will be enough to easily resolve any lines that are visible in the band.

The requested angular resolution will give us ~100 independent resolution elements for each source, which is easily enough given the number of free parameters in the lensing model. Our simulations (see above) show that although we might detect gravitational arcs with a size similar to the maximum recoverable scale, we will actually lose very little sensitivity because most of the power in the Fourier domain is on much smaller scales.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: GAMA 9 field (east)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Targets within GAMA 9 field with RA>09:00:00.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:

Using the lens model that we have derived for the Herschel source ID81 (Dye et al. 2014), we find that the emission is spread over 105 beam areas. To ascertain whether loss of flux is important, we have used the ALMA Observation Tool to observe our simulated lensed source (diameter of Einstein ring of 3 arcsec), finding that the loss of flux in the ring is <5%.

As a conservative assumption, when we investigated the accuracy with which we could recover the source structures and density profiles (Fig. 3a), we have used the beam size for this source.
The spectral resolution (27 km/s) will be enough to resolve any lines in the band
The chosen angular resolution will produce ~100 independent beam areas, enough to constrain all the parameters in the lensing model. See above for a discussion of the largest angular scale.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:

Requiring a 5sigma detection in each beam, we obtain a similar sensitivity requirement to the one from the first assumption.

To ascertain whether loss of flux is important, we have used the ALMA Observation Tool to observe our simulated lensed source (diameter of Einstein ring of 3 arcsec), finding that the loss of flux in the ring is <5%.

The chosen angular resolution will produce ~100 independent beams areas, enough to constrain all the parameters in the lensing model. See above for a discussion of the largest angular scale.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGP field (southeast)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Targets within NGP field with RA>13:00:00 and Dec<+30:00:00.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We have used the redshifts and the Herschel fluxes to predict the total flux in Band 7 for each source. The predicted fluxes range between 50 and 150 mJy. We have calculated the required sensitivity in two ways. First, we assume that there is no structure on a scale larger than 1 arcsec, the scale of the structure detected by Bussmann et al. (2013). To be conservative we assume that the source emission is spread over a circle of diameter 1 arcsec, equivalent to 70 resolution elements (beam of 0.12 arcsec). We calculate the integration times by requiring a 5sigma detection in each beam area. Second, we assume that the emission is distributed in an Einstein ring of diameter 3 arcsec. Using the lens model that we have derived for the Herschel source ID81 (Dye et al. 2014), we find that the emission is spread over 105 beam areas. Requiring a 5sigma detection in each beam, we obtain a similar sensitivity requirement to the one from the first assumption.
In the latter test case, the maximum scale for Band 7 is similar to the scale of the lensing signal that we are looking for. However, for gravitational rings and arcs, most of the power in the fourier domain is on smaller scales. To ascertain whether loss of flux is important, we have used the ALMA Observation Simulation Tool to observe our simulated lensed source (diameter of Einstein ring of 3 arcsec), finding that the loss of flux in the ring is <5%.
The source in our sample that will be at the lowest elevation from ALMA is at a declination of 35 degrees, where the beam size in declination is increased by a factor of 1.8. As a conservative assumption, when we investigated the accuracy with which we could recover the source structures and density profiles (Fig. 3a), we have used the beam size for this source.
The spectral resolution (27 km/s) will be enough to resolve any lines in the band.
The resolution will produce ~100 independent beam areas, enough to constrain all the parameters in the lensing model. See above for a discussion of the largest angular scale.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The use of gravitational lenses as a tool for cosmology has been limited by the small sizes of samples of lenses, but the discovery that most bright submillimetre sources are lensed is on the verge of revolutionising this field. We propose to obtain ALMA observations of 41 bright Herschel lensed sources for which we already have redshifts. We will use the ALMA maps to determine the density distribution around each lens and to reconstruct the unlensed source emission. We will use the results to make an immediate test of the theoretical predictions of the mass function of dark-matter halos, on which all current models of galaxy and cluster evolution are based. By combining the ALMA results with high-resolution imaging with the HST, we will investigate separately the evolution of the baryons and the dark matter. Since the reconstructed images of the source emission will have a physical resolution of approximately the size of giant molecular cloud, we will also obtain a superbly detailed picture of the interstellar medium in a large sample of galaxies only 1-2 billion years after the Big Bang
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: Riechers et al. are proposing to obtain [CII] observations of a sample of lensed Herschel sources. This includes Band 7 observations of three of our 41 targets.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
